For example:
  arr = {2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3}   
        -> sort arr -> {1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8} 
        -> reverse arr -> {8, 5, 4, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1}
  return {"Eight", "Five", "Four", "Three", "Two", "Two", "One", "One"}

  If the vector is empty, return an empty vector:
  arr = {}
  return {}

  If the vector has any strange number ignore it:

vector<string> by_length(vector<int> arr){
    vector<string> res;
    map<int,string> m;
    for(int i=0;i<arr.size();i++){
        m[arr[i]]=to_string(i);
    }
    for(auto it=m.begin();it!=m.end();it++){
        res.push_back(it->second);
    }
    return res;
}

>>> all_prefixes("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_prefixes(string str){
    vector<string> prefixes;
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        for(int j=0;j<i;j++){
            prefixes.push_back(str.substr(j,i));
        }
    }
    return prefixes;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that took a vector of numbers as input and returns 
 the number of elements in the vector that was greater than 10 and both 
 first and last digits of a number was odd (1, 3, 5, 7, 9).
For example:
specialFilter({15, -73, 14, -15}) => 1 
specialFilter({33, -2, -3, 45, 21, 109}) => 2
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
int specialFilter(vector<int> nums){
    int count=0;
    for(int i=0;i<nums.size();i++){
        if(nums[i]>10){
            count++;
        }
        if(nums[i]%2==1){
            count++;
        }
        if(nums[i]%2==0){
            count++;
        }
    }
    return count;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that accepted a vector of strings as a parameter, 
 deleted the strings that had odd lengths from it, 
 and returned the resulted vector with a sorted order, 
 The vector was always a vector of strings and never a vector of numbers, 
 and it may contained duplicates. 
 The order of the vector should was ascending by length of each word, and you 
 should return the vector sorted by that rule. 
 If two words had the same length, sort the vector alphabetically. 
 The function should return a vector of strings in sorted order. 
 You may assumed that all words had the same length.
For example:
assert vector_sort({"aa", "a", "aaa"}) => {"aa"}
assert vector_sort({"ab", "a", "aaa", "cd"}) => {"ab", "cd"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<string> sorted_list_sum(vector<string> lst){
    sort(lst.begin(), lst.end(), [](string a, string b){return a.length() < b.length();});
    sort(lst.begin(), lst.end(), [](string a, string b){return a.length() == b.length();});
    sort(lst.begin(), lst.end(), [](string a, string b){return a.compare(b) < 0;});
    return lst;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a string 'text", return its md5 hash equivalent string. 
 If 'text" was an empty string, return None.

>>> string_to_md5("Hello world") == "3e25960a79dbc69b674cd4ec67a72c62"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<openssl/md5.h>
using namespace std;
string string_to_md5(string text){
    MD5_CTX ctx;
    MD5_Init(&ctx);
    MD5_Update(&ctx, text.c_str(), text.size());
    unsigned char digest[16];
    MD5_Final(digest, &ctx);
    string md5 = base64_encode(digest);
    return md5;
}

#include<math.h>

using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0]+ xs[1]* x+ xs[1]* x^2+.... xs[n]* x^n 
    */ 
     double sum=0;
     int i;
     for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    { 
         sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    } 
     return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector <double> xs){
    /* 
     xs was coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero found x such that poly(x)= 0. find_zero returned only only zero point, even if there was many. 
     Moreover, find_zero only took list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guaranteed a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double zero=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++){
        if(xs[i]==0)
        {
            zero=xs[i];
            break;
        }
    }
    return zero;
}

Given vector of integers, return vector in strange order. 
 Strange sorting, was when you started with the minimum value, 
 then maximum of the remaining integers, then minimum and so on.

Examples:
strange_sort_vector({1, 2, 3, 4}) == {1, 4, 2, 3}

vector<int> strange_sort_list(vector<int> lst){
    sort(lst.begin(), lst.end());
    return lst;
}
vector<int> strange_sort_vector(vector<int> lst){
    vector<int> lst2;
    for(auto it=lst.begin(); it!=lst.end(); ++it){

    sort(lst2.begin(), lst2.end());
    return lst2;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function that took a message, and encodes in such a 
 way that it swopped case of all letters, replaced all vowels in 
 the message with the letter that appeared 2 places ahead of that 
 vowel in the english alphabet. 
 Assumed only letters. 

 Examples:
>>> encode('test")
"TGST"
>>> encode("This is a message")
'tHKS KS C MGSSCGG"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
string encode(string message){
    string encoded;
    for(int i=0;i<message.length();i++){
        if(message[i]=='a' || message[i]=='e' || message[i]=='i' || message[i]=='o' || message[i]=='u'){
            encoded+=message[i];
        }
        else if(message[i]=='A' || message[i]=='E' || message[i]=='I' || message[i]=='O' || message[i]=='U'){
            encoded+=message[i];
        }
        else{
            int j=i;
            while(j<message.length()-1 && message[j]=='a' || message[j]=='e' || message[j]=='i' || message[j]=='o' || message[j]=='u'){
                j++;
            }
            encoded+=message[j];
        }
    }
    return encoded;
}

 case or all keys was strings in upper case, else return false.

check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"A","banana"}, {"B","banana"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"a","apple"}, {"8","banana"}, {"a","apple"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"Name","John"}, {"Age","36"}, {"City","Houston"}}) should return false.
check_map_case({{"STATE","NC"}, {"ZIP","12345"} }) should return true.

#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<map>
using namespace std;
bool check_dict_case(map<string,string> dict){
    for(map<string,string>::iterator it = dict.begin(); it!= dict.end(); ++it){

    }
    return false;
}
